http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Heralded as the great event of the year, the completion of this Russian-Japanese-Chinese link in 1871 brought British interests in China into “instantaneous communication with London” through a much-needed secondary route. News of the project inspired a demonstration of the technology for a pair of Canton officials. As British administrators report, both “showed interest and appreciation; and we hope their experience may tend to remove the prejudice with which electricity, like every other novelty, has been hitherto regarded in China.”

http://purl.org/dc/terms/title.value: Telegraph Bay, Pok Fu Lam, Hong Kong

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Barty-King: from here they connected to Eastern Extension office at Marine Hour – on the site occupied by Old Mercury House in 1979.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In nineteenth-century Hong Kong, a barrage of undersea cables – from Singapore, Shanghai, Fuzhou, Manila, Labuan, and Macau – landed at Telegraph Bay. From here, cables wound inland across the island’s northern shore, through the city center to the busy Eastern Extension cable office. The daily work of cablemen at “Electra House,” as it was called, was eventful. Traffic was re-directed from one network to another, messages linked local commerce into a global economy, and important political information was relayed about British-Chinese relations. Yet as they sustained the network, cablemen also worried about sustaining themselves. They were concerned about finding healthy food (one worried that local vegetables were not clean enough to eat) and about catching the plague (another remarked that “Hong Kong would not be Hong Kong if we didn’t have an epidemic of something every year”). And leading up to World War II, a cableman recounted, “Life in Hong Kong has been subject to rude jolts during recent years… we had quite a few delightful moments dealing with traffic which poured in for places which had been 'interrupted by bomb.'” Not long after, station life would be interrupted completely when the Japanese took over the island. Today the work of Hong Kong’s cablemen has moved to the island’s southern shore, but Telegraph Bay remains a center of information exchange. It is now the location of the expansive Cyberport, a “creative digital community” built to foster technology development.

“CABLE SITUATION AT AMOY. MUCH DISCONTENT” reads the headline in a 1931 Singapore newspaper. “The prosperity of business in Amoy largely depends upon its rapid communications by cable to the South Seas,” the article explains, but telegrams “intended for Amoy are now relayed to Shanghai.” Service was disrupted when, a few days prior, Chinese officials shut down the Great Northern Telegraph Company office on Kulangsu Island, where a Danish cable stopped on its way from Hong Kong and Shanghai. This cable originally bypassed Amoy, but in 1873, the company added a branch to the city without Chinese permission and began profiting from the added traffic. When China took control of the Kulangsu-Amoy connection in 1931, it disrupted local businesses already heavily reliant on submarine telegraphy.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: As a key British treaty port in the wake of the first Opium War, Shanghai rapidly developed as a contact zone for international powers. The city brought together a mix of cultures, architectural styles, and social classes, but these connections were made possible by the exploitation of Chinese labor and a concession system that granted foreigners immunity to Chinese law. The first telegraph cable arrived in 1871, covertly brought ashore in the middle of the night by the Great Northern Telegraph Company. In the ensuing years more cables were laid without official Chinese sanction. Without the cooperation of the Chinese people, however, cables remained vulnerable to disruption. Enterprising pirates stripped cables for resale. Local villagers ripped down lines that disturbed ancestral grave sites and the landscape’s feng shui. Men armed with rifles had to patrol the Yangtze River to stop sailors from throwing anchor and severing the cable. The situation was ameliorated by degrees when, in 1875, the Chinese government offered official recognition and protection to the cables in exchange for ownership of the illegal lines upstream of Shanghai. A period of relative stability followed, as China slowly developed an overland monopoly on telegraph lines while colonial powers built ever more underwater connections.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: On AtlanticCable.com, many landings indicated by "Mogi, Nagasaki-ken, Japan"

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Like many port cities in Asia, Nagasaki was “discovered” by imperial powers – in this case, the Portuguese – and developed for trade. In the nineteenth century, Nagasaki became a busy transit point, with a vibrant ship-building industry, an anchorage site for the Japanese navy, and a telegraph cable landing point. Three years after its first submarine telegraph cable was landed in 1871, the telegraph company established a headquarters here, in a large two-story office building abutting the harbor. Within a few years, Japan would build up its internal landlines, and the country would be connected to the rest of the world via Nagasaki. The importance of this station was clear to Japan and its enemies. Described as “clutching the aeortic artery of international communications in Japan,” Nagasaki, as a hub and military harbor, was also a target. The cable to Vladivostok was taken out of service during the Russo-Japanese War, but the city remained undamaged. During World War II, however, Nagasaki was hit with the atomic bomb, the second and last to ever be deployed, killing several hundred thousand people. After the Japanese surrender, the city would slowly rebuild. Old communications lines were taken out of service, and new coaxial cables laid in their place.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Founded in 1860 as a Russian naval post, the city of Vladivostok, “Ruler of the East," is fraught with contradictions. In the late 1800s, the military presence permeated the city, but the orderliness it instituted was offset by sailors’ gambling and drunkenness. At the same time, Vladivostok was a cosmopolitan center filled with a “polyglot crowd.” Businessmen from around the world were drawn by the city’s natural harbor and investor privileges. The Danish Great Northern Telegraph Company used Vladivostok as a connection point for their trans-Siberian cable and undersea links to Nagasaki and Shanghai – an important alternative to the British-dominated global network. The cable boosted the city’s international business as well as the dissemination of naval intelligence, and the telegraph company was granted a forty-year lease on a prime piece of land. Several cablemen were employed in a stately three-story office building to handle the traffic. In the 1930s, under Joseph Stalin’s repressive regime, Vladivostok changed profoundly. Many of its ethnic inhabitants were forcibly removed, and the city became a distribution point for Stalin’s political prisoners. Fearing espionage, the government removed foreigners from the Great Northern telegraph stations, and the cable line was left in Russian hands. In the following years, as Vladivostok changed from “colony of non-Russian powers” to a “city of workers,” multi-story apartment buildings were constructed where the telegraph office once stood, with statues of a worker, a farmer, a sailor, and a guard adorning the rooftop. Today the building has returned to its international roots: it is home to the Barbados Hostel.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: This tag specifies that the associated page is a cable.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Across history, there have been three kinds of cable technology: copper telegraph cables, coaxial telephone cables, and fiber-optic internet cables. To create a page for a new cable, see the reference page for cables.

The Southern Cross Cable Network was designed as an Internet-based cable that, at the time, would be the fastest and most straightforward route from Australia and New Zealand to the United States. Just as Southern Cross was being put in the water, the cable market collapsed – this was brought on by a combination of the excess capacity offered by the numerous cable systems laid in the late 1990s. The timing of Southern Cross was “perfect,” as its builders recollect, poised on the crest of the cable boom: if they'd started a little bit later, it likely wouldn't have happened.

At the turn of the twenty-first century, three cables came ashore on the rural coast of western Oregon. While systems of the coaxial period usually terminated close to shore, these lines wound inland for over seventy miles, through the fir-populated mountains of the Tillamook State Forest to a Portland suburb nestled in the heart of “Silicon Forest.” The area was granted this nickname in 1981, only a few years after Intel established a research campus there. Yet the seeds of Silicon Forest were planted much earlier. In the 1930s, the U.S. Forest Service Radio Lab was created in Portland, and built wireless technologies to track fires as they spread through the forest, including the one that now borders the cable route. Engineers at the Radio Lab eventually developed two of Portland’s most well-known technology companies, setting the stage for today’s high-tech boom. Hillsboro, Oregon is now home to computer researchers, chip manufacturers, and cable stations, and is a budding hub of data center activity. Companies are drawn to Silicon Forest because of its “welcoming” environment: not only do companies get massive tax breaks in Hillsboro’s E-Commerce zone, but they have immediate access to cheap hydroelectric power from the nearby Columbia River.

Electric Beach, on O‘ahu’s west shore, is named for the large power plant towering behind it and known for regular car burglaries. Three men casually fish off the edge of the point. Families barbeque. A manhole is covered in rusty red dirt. Moving under this manhole, through the cable, and out to the ocean, you briefly pass a small cave with hanging clothes, stockpiled chairs, and collected water. The same beach that makes possible the landing of communications cables – infrastructures that accelerate the movement of information across the oceans – is also a temporary dwelling for some of the least mobile Hawaiians. The Kahe Point station, constructed just north of Electric Beach, has managed to stay out of view, and therefore out of local politics.

Moving across this cable landing, you are careful not to sink into the ditches that dot the landscape. Trash clutters the beach, and nearby, shots are fired at the end of Rifle Range Road. The station at Vatuwaqa, like so many others, was built in a largely industrial, suburban area just north of Fiji's capital city, Suva. Yet unlike many contemporary cable stations, it is a place where people as well as signals come together. Men who work for Fiji's international telecommunications company are hanging out around the building. A dog lazily watches the front gate. Inside is a room constructed specifically for teleconferencing, where the company imagined new kinds of business relationships would emerge. As you pass through, you find a sense of camaraderie and hospitality among the cable workers. This is a place for meeting, for connecting, and for understanding cable history. In the courtyard, a monument commemorates the site's development as a satellite earth station, the landing point of the ANZCAN cable, and later, the Southern Cross system.

Arriving from the Southern Cross Cable Network, you surface on Narrabeen Beach, unhindered by fishing nets, boat anchors, or dredging equipment. These activities are prohibited in this government-sanctioned cable protection area, one of two established in Sydney in 2005. Once ashore, you travel four miles south to Brookvale, which has been a commercial and industrial center in North Sydney since the 1950s. The station blends in with surrounding businesses: sign printers, auto body shops, and several well-known surfboard manufacturers. As dents are repaired and signals enter local networks, many of the boards crafted in Brookvale end up back in the waves off Narrabeen Beach where volunteer lifeguards operate out of local surf clubs. This safe-zone for surfers and cables is the only Australian site mentioned in the 1963 Beach Boys hit “Surfin’ U.S.A.”

Situated in an office park, the Alexandria cable station is just a few hundred feet from the Alexandra Canal, built in the late nineteenth century to provide barge access to South Sydney. By the 1940s, Alexandria had more than five hundred factories producing bricks, wool fabrics, airplane parts, and other goods, as well as a branch of the Standard Telephones and Cables Company. Set up to provide voice links to Britain in the early twentieth century, Standard went on to manufacture underwater cables, including one between Sydney and Vancouver in the 1980s. Despite its proximity to the station, cables don’t surface in the canal, now widely considered the most polluted waterway in Australia. Instead, lines from the Southern Cross system arrive near the historical cable landing at Bondi Beach before heading inland to Alexandria. Here, connections are made to several nearby data centers, drawn to the area by the presence of the cable head.

On New Zealand’s rural west coast, a coaxial cable extends out from a sand bank, over a small pond of water, and back into the beach before it heads to Sydney. Aquatic creatures have incorporated its eroding armor and still strong copper core into their home. Old cables dating to the telegraph era have surfaced on this beach: the first international link landed over a century ago, in 1912. Cost-cutting during the Depression prompted the cable company to re-locate a second link, formerly in Wellington, here in 1932. From Muriwai cables extend inland over twenty miles to the growing city of Auckland. This terrestrial path is almost as fraught as the surf-beaten shores of Muriwai. In 1952, incorrectly gauging the location of the cable system, a road grader severed the international network for five hours. After this, the cable companies ensured that the network was marked extensively for the local community.

This northern suburb of Auckland, New Zealand, has been an outlet for northward communications for more than a century. In 1912, after a new Chief Post Office was opened in central Auckland, the Pacific Cable Board re-directed their cable from rural Doubtless Bay to Takapuna Beach. The workers from the station came with the cable, and the cable station was set up on in the Post Office, consolidating networks formerly distributed across the land. As the cable continued to function without major disruptions, networks in the following decades continued to follow the same path. When the Southern Cross Internet cable was set up in 2000, it too landed on the Takapuna shore. In the cable industry, the prevailing logic is to go with the tried and true.

To many early visitors, Kawaihae appeared a barren and desolate place. Its arid landscape on the leeward side of Hawai’i’s big island supported little agriculture. Despite this, in the late 1700s it was the residence of King Kamehameha and a staging ground for the conquest of the Hawaiian archipelago. Though the translation of Kawaihae is “Water-of-Wrath,” like Kamehameha, many of the area’s early residents used the water to their advantage, trading both fish and salt extracted from the ocean. Kawaihae’s sheltered bay also brought European merchants ashore, transforming the community into a “depot of goods for the interior.” Cattle were imported and native Hawaiians were forced to harvest sandalwood from the island’s interior forests. The exchange of goods made local resources even more scarce. The cattle ran wild, endangering residents and destroying Kawaihae’s cultivated land. The sandalwood trade brought about massive deforestation. Although Kawaihae’s port receded in importance in the late 1800s, trade has since been revived. In 1970, the United States Army Corps of Engineers excavated the harbor with nuclear explosives, making way for imports and exports once again. Undersea cables land not far from the port, connecting the area to New Zealand, Tahiti, California, and the rest of the archipelago.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: You land on a beach on the Central California coast. You're in between two of the first nodes for internet traffic, Stanford University and the University of California Santa Barbara, and two hundred miles from the major internet technology hub in Silicon Valley. This is where the Internet enters the United States via undersea cable. The landscape is anything but technological. Behind you, an expansive state park wraps around the California coast. It is cold and rainy. Fog covers the ocean, but it deters neither surfers nor the signals transiting invisibly beneath the beach. From here, signals extend outward to Hawai'i, Guam, Japan, and onward to much of Asia. In what direction will you go?

Fiber-optic cables encode signals in light and send them down a thread of glass. Although in development since the early 1980s, the conservative cable industry did not lay the first transoceanic network until 1986. The immense capacity of fiber-optics have made possible the Internet as we know it today.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: This tag specifies a path that should operate as a ring, with the last page connecting back to the first page

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: To ensure redundancy, some cable systems are laid in a ring, with two given paths between any two points. This is an expensive approach to network design, but if one segment breaks, traffic can automatically be re-routed in opposite direction. During the cable boom of the 1990s, many ring systems were built, providing diverse routes to stations such as Miyazaki and Ninomiya in Japan.

The Southern Cross Cable Network was designed as an Internet-based cable that, at the time, would be the fastest and most straightforward route from Australia and New Zealand to the United States. Just as Southern Cross was being put in the water, the cable market collapsed – this was brought on by a combination of the excess capacity offered by the numerous cable systems laid in the late 1990s. The timing of Southern Cross was “perfect,” as its builders recollect, poised on the crest of the cable boom: if they'd started a little bit later, it likely wouldn't have happened.

Sanford Fleming and the Canadian Government mobilized arguments about security to establish the first transpacific cable system in 1902, creating a foundational route for all north-south Pacific traffic. This system mastered the scale of the globe: the Pacific Cable Board line between Bamfield, Canada and Fanning Island was then the longest undersea cable in the world. This system also required new expenditures for infrastructure and planning. A new 8,000 ton ship, the Colonia, had to be constructed specifically for the line.

Bamfield was a critical gateway during the telegraph era, a site where international signals punctured Canada and threaded it to other territories around the world. Yet this station was considered one of the most remote places in the Pacific Cable Board’s network due to the difficulties of regional transport. The nearby inlet was known as the “graveyard of the Pacific” for its numerous wrecks; the coastal Telegraph Trail served as a lifeline for their survivors. One cableman recollects that even though it was only one hundred and twenty miles to Victoria, the largest city on Vancouver Island, “you might as well have been a thousand miles away for all the difficulties in transportation.” The town had no road access until 1963 and in order to visit, one has to drive hours along narrow gravel logging roads, avoiding trucks that barrel down without warning and stir up clouds of dust in their wake. In the small town, which consists of a motel, a bar, and a handful of stores, young people are strolling along the streets, divers are suiting up, and trucks are fitted out for recreational camping. Bamfield would not be a destination for so many visitors if it were not for the establishment of a marine science center, which transformed the abandoned cable station into labs and classrooms.

Fanning Island was linked via the Pacific Cable Board’s telegraph cable in 1902, becoming an integral part of the British Empire’s communications network. Ernest Shackelton, famed Antarctic explorer, once wrote a poem about the island: “Surf-bound, lonely islet, Set in a summer sea, Work of a tiny insect, A lesson I learn from Thee— For to your foam-white shores, The deep sea cables come; Through slippery ooze, by feathery palm, Flies by the busy hum, Of Nations linked together, The young with the older lands, A moment’s space, and the Northern tale Is placed in Southern hands.” Despite the Empire’s dependence on Fanning, it was the most geographically remote station on the line, and cablemen dreaded moving there. Many men were separated from their families for over two years, and the station’s sports and camaraderie were little substitute for the comforts of home. In part because of the island’s poor infrastructure, when coaxial cable replaced the telegraph in the 1960s, Fanning was bypassed, the cablemen left, and an era ended for the island’s Gilbertese inhabitants.

You come ashore via a British cable, laid in 1902 to connect colonial holdings across the Pacific. This link not only brought colonial commands, but external business investment, especially in Fiji's growing agriculture industry. As the cable brought market rates, ships brought indentured Indian laborers to work the sugar plantations. The island's economic development made it a well-liked hub by transiting cable men, who wrote about the station's short working hours, annual balls held by local sports clubs, and picnic trips up the river. By the mid-twentieth century, Fiji had become a full-fledged communications hub for the South Pacific, the only island with an extensive wireless network and cable routes to the north and south. It was not only British men who operated these systems. Local opportunities were developed for training and labor, including a wireless telegraph school and a cable depot. Fijian and Indo-Fijians, as well as Gilbertese, Ellice Islanders, and Solomon Islanders, helped to run the South Pacific communications network. Fiji not only depended on foreign signal traffic, but major Western powers depended on local infrastructures and support.

There are only a few ways to get ashore at Norfolk Island. Rough seas batter the island’s high, rocky walls. There are no harbors or ports. Strong currents make entry difficult at the one feasible cable landing site, Anson Bay, and even here landslides can take out the hillside. Despite these difficulties, the island was determined to be the only feasible geographic location to land the first transpacific cable after it snaked down from Fiji and before it branched off to Australia and New Zealand. Norfolk’s inaccessibility had once made it an ideal location for a convict settlement, yet this had been closed almost fifty years prior to the cable’s arrival. Migrants from Pitcairn, the descendants of the Bounty mutineers, have taken up residence in the penal buildings. The island’s insularity coupled with a lack of cable traffic produced a set of unique connections here. For a period of time, the cableman on night duty in Southport would send newspaper extracts to Norfolk Island, where they were typed up by the operator and “tacked up on a tree at the crossroads for all to read.” This news source was known as the “Tree of Knowledge.” By the 1920s, with the development of automatic relays, far fewer staff were needed on Norfolk Island and the cable community diminished.

The first transpacific cable terminated in Southport, a small coastal town not far from Brisbane, the capital of Queensland, Australia. In 1901, prior to the cable's arrival, the town's population was a mere 1230 people. From Southport, traffic was then routed by land to Sydney, but this terrestrial connection was one of the least stable segments of the entire transpacific cable. Aboriginal inhabitants regularly cut down the line. Despite the fickle land-line, this cable station operated for sixty years, closing in July 1962. Even after it stopped transmitting international messages, the cable station continued to have a legacy in the beach town. In the 1980s, when the buildings were under threat of demolition, residents spearheaded a campaign to save them. The cable station was renovated, restored, and moved to become the Music Department of the nearby Southport School. Today a park, a street, and an apartment building have all been named after the area's former transpacific cable.

Sanford Fleming and the Canadian Government mobilized arguments about security to establish the first transpacific cable system in 1902, creating a foundational route for all north-south Pacific traffic. This system mastered the scale of the globe: the Pacific Cable Board line between Bamfield, Canada and Fanning Island was then the longest undersea cable in the world. This system also required new expenditures for infrastructure and planning. A new 8,000 ton ship, the Colonia, had to be constructed specifically for the line.

Heading inland to the Makaha cable station, you surface in a parking lot, in a manhole barely visible under the dirt. Along the beaches to the south of this town reside hundreds of houseless people. O‘ahu’s west shore is home to one of the state’s largest native communities and largest homeless population. In Makaha alone, 32% of its residents live in poverty. Yet, the west shore is also a transit point for a large percentage of the state’s international signal traffic. Since the 1960s, almost all of the island’s coaxial and fiber-optic cables have terminated at three cable stations along this short 30-kilometer stretch. The seemingly divergent histories of telecommunications success and economic deprivation in the area are intertwined, and linked to the area's long-standing military occupation. Weapons testing sites and military installations, such as the Lualualei Naval Reservation and the Schofield Barracks, displaced residents from the west shore’s inland valleys. At the same time, the U.S. military was once one of the biggest customers of the cable networks, giving them both an economic boost and a layer of protection when they were set up during the Cold War.

Landing on Midway, you glide up a soft white beach to green grasses. Before 1903, the island was completely desolate, with little vegetation or life. When the Commercial Pacific Cable Company established the Midway cable station, the high winds and blinding glare of the white sand meant that cablemen had to wear goggles when they went outside. Shiploads of soil were brought in from Hawai‘i so that the men could plant grass. The cable company also imported chickens, cows, trees, and other plants to make the area shady and sustainable. One cablemen recounted that they had found the island “bare and have made it beautiful.” Life on Midway was quiet and often lonely for the twenty-four men stationed there, over 1300 miles away from the nearest inhabited island, but they took pride in their tropical home, broadcasting its happenings in the cable network’s magazine. After the Second World War, and the infamous battle that occurred here, Midway continued to be an important node in cable networks, first as a stopping point for a transpacific telephone cable and later as a cable listening post for the U.S. Navy's Sound Surveillance System.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: A mere twelve feet above sea level, this string of three islands is the only evidence of a massive volcano that lies beneath. Wake, Pearle, and Wilkes Island wrap around a shallow, vibrant blue lagoon, the volcano's empty crater. Dangers are hidden on the atoll's shores, in the military installations from which the United States coordinates another kind of aerial explosion: military missile testing. Were it not for undersea cables, this island might never have become a United States possession. It was discovered in 1568 by Spanish explorers, but was dubbed a “low barren island.” In 1899, the US government annexed Wake Island with the hope of landing a cable there, but given the lack of fresh water and its inhospitable conditions, a station was never built. It was not until after the historic battle on Wake Island during World War II that it finally became a cable node. In 1964, the United States and Japan cooperated to land the first transpacific telephone cable here. Although all subsequent systems skipped over the island, Wake continues to serve a strategic function. Hydroacoustic arrays extend out to the seafloor, monitoring for underwater nuclear activity in the Western Pacific.

“Wake Atoll,” U.S. Department of the Interior, Office of Insular Affairs, accessed June 7, 2013, http://www.doi.gov/oia/islands/wakeatoll.cfm.

“HA11, Wake Island, United States Territory,” CTBTO Preparatory Commission, accessed July 7, 2013, http://www.ctbto.org/verification-regime/featured-stations/types/hydroacoustic/ha11-wake-islandunited-states-territory/.

Dirk van Oudenol, “CS Restorer,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed June 7, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cableships/Restorer/1901.htm.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The Tanguisson Beach station, built to house American networks during the Cold War era, resembles an underground bunker. Entering, you descend several stories down a fortified stairwell and even then, can only access the equipment room once admitted through a secure metal door. Immediately inside the entrance is a decontamination chamber, a former precaution for nuclear attack, and now a storage closet. Everything inside is redundant in case the domestic infrastructure fails. Multiple, completely separated generators comprise backups for building power and air-conditioning units. Independent battery plants sustain the equipment. During the coaxial era, Tanguisson was staffed by at least two employees at all times, but was often occupied by many more. On the wall, you witness evidence of the community formed here: yearbook-style photos of all of the AT&T stations in the Pacific, including Makaha, Keawa‘ula, Bandon, San Luis Obispo, and Point Arena. Each has an image of the station and photos of the people who worked there, with their name and position listed underneath, grouped as a school class would be. Photographs of the cable ships, AT&T cable landings, and maps of Guam decorate the walls. Due to the massive downsizings that have occurred since the 1980s, far fewer people work at Tanguisson today. The cable community, however, still exists.

Ninomiya was the first landing site for trans-Pacific coaxial cables in Japan, built in 1964 to receive TPC-1 from Guam. As one of the oldest still-operational stations in the country, it served as a training ground for Japanese cable workers, some of whom later became leaders in the industry. For a period of time, it was also a hotbed of submarine cable research, where new cable technologies were designed and developed. Unlike many modern stations, however, it is located in a central residential area populated by commuters to Odawara and Tokyo-Yokohama. Even though Ninomiya is linked to these urban areas, the greenery of Azumayama Park makes them easy to leave behind. Climb up the hill behind the station and you will enter the park, passing several shrines and temples on your journey to the summit. Dense woods open onto a grassy plain with commanding views of Sagami Bay and Mount Fuji. Artist Hokusai Katsushika included this vista in his series of woodblock prints of Fuji as seen from different Japanese towns, drawing Ninomiya into an early-nineteenth-century visual network.

Completed in 1964, Trans-Pacific Cable 1 was the first coaxial cable to link Japan and the U.S. via landing sites in Guam and Hawai'i. It was also part of a global communications network that linked tracking stations, command centers, and other infrastructure during the Apollo missions, including the moon landing in 1969. TPC-1 carried voice signals across the ocean for twenty-six years and, since 1990, the decommissioned cable has been used to study earthquakes.

Trans-Pacific Cable 5 was one of the first ring systems in the Pacific. It has two branches between Japan and the U.S.: a direct northern route and a southern crossing via Hawai'i and Guam, where it interconnects with other global networks. More than 70 telecom companies from over 40 countries were involved in its construction, and two-thirds of its capacity was reserved before it entered service in the mid-1990s. TPC-5’s southern line carried high-definition television broadcasts for the 1996 Summer Olympic Games in Atlanta.

Long before Bandon became AT&T’s outpost in rural Oregon, it was a critical node in an undersea cable network: the U.S. military’s Sound Surveillance System (SOSUS). From the Pacific coast, SOSUS connected hydrophones and picked up sonic traces of subaquatic movements, from the deployment of Soviet submarines to migrations of whales. Officers stationed at Naval Facility Coos Head tuned into these underwater listening posts and collected data on enemy operations. The Coos Head facility, first opened in 1958, was closed twenty-nine years later in 1987. Improvements in signal-processing had replaced manpower with computers, and as the Cold War wound down the number of Naval Facilities was reduced. Given AT&T’s tight ties with the U.S. Navy, and their assistance in developing SOSUS, it was unsurprising when nine years later, they chose Bandon as a landing point for their newest transpacific cable system, TPC-5.

This rural station in Central California has been a cable hub since 1964, when a telephone cable to Hawai'i was routed through Morro Bay. Constructed by AT&T, its location was midway between San Francisco and Los Angeles placed it out of the way of potential nuclear attack. Although the state has been a hub in communication technology, it has also played an important role in the growth of the environmental movement and the preservation of wilderness areas. Daniel Press articulates the apparent contradiction: “at the vanguard of paradoxical trends, California is one of the fastest growing states in the country, but is the most ambivalent about change.” Today, Central California is a site of conflict between these two forces. Fishermen and environmentalists regularly pose challenges to infrastructure development.

In 1962, the balance of undersea cable power was shifting from British companies to the Americans. The Keawa‘ula cable station had just been built on O‘ahu’s west shore to land the Commonwealth Pacific Cable (COMPAC). British and Canadian transoceanic lines no longer stopped at Fanning Island, but rather, on United States soil. As a result, the construction of their cable station accorded with U.S. military specifications: it was located underground in a nuclear fallout shelter with thick walls and a decontamination chamber. Arriving at this station today, you see an elegant set of steps up leading up to a front wall comprised of square glass blocks. One transmission engineer describes Keawa‘ula as a “palace.” Designed by a local Honolulu-based firm, the station's aboveground expansion was inspired by a visit from the CEO of Teleglobe Canada in the 1980s. With little space for gathering inside, the staff members at the time held their meeting in a small and cramped lunch room. Afterward, the CEO saw the station workers outside, joking around and hanging out in the trees. In part inspired by the cable community, Teleglobe built a new, staff-friendly environment. The re-designed station grounded the communication hub in the heart of the cable family, yet left intact its Cold War foundations.

Tourists step on a long cable conduit without looking twice, intent on getting to the ruins of a World War II Japanese antiaircraft gun at the far end of Gun Beach. Few realize that Guam's strategic military value during the war was in part due to its undersea cable networks. Even fewer realize that the island remains one of the most connected places in the Pacific, with cables stretching out from its shores to the mainland United States, Asia, and Australia. At the other end of the beach is the Hotel Nikko, one of the early Japanese five-star hotels in the area, a building dependent on the island’s advanced communications infrastructure. At Tumon Bay, undersea cables bisect a material remnant of the Japanese wartime attack and one of the largest indications of Japanese development on the island, two sites with which cable communications are intertwined. The cable conduits themselves are worn down and blend in with the rocks on the beach. In the water their surfaces are smooth, but rippled, like the ocean. In them, one can see traces of the atmospheric and geological currents that have long positioned Guam at the center of transpacific movements.

From a mostly undeveloped beach several miles north of Miyazaki, you follow a dirt path inland until it opens onto a single-lane road. In the distance, a ringed communications tower is visible above the treetops. Homing in on this beacon, you reach a windowless building surrounded on all sides by a barbed-wire fence. Three majestic palm trees and a plaque bearing the logo of Japanese telecom company KDDI mark the entrance, while farmland and greenhouses occupy the surrounding plots. In 1977, the first telephone cable arrived from Okinawa, where a trans-Pacific link to the U.S. had recently been completed. Optical cables followed in the 1990s, but more recent connections have overlooked Miyazaki in favor of the cluster of hubs along the east coast of Honshu Island.

A trading post since the second century, the island of Singapore was a hub of exchange for Southeast Asia long before the British settled there in 1819. When the first underwater telegraph cable arrived forty years later, Singapore was a bustling port city, what one nineteenth-century cable survey called “that thriving halfway house between Europe and the East.” Although produced in a factory in London more than six thousand miles away, the Singapore-Muntok cable was insulated with the coagulated sap of trees native to the region. The Malays had used this substance, known as gutta-percha, for generations to make whips and other products. In the 1840s, a Scottish doctor stationed in Singapore took notice of the sap and brought it back to London. Gutta-percha made an ideal electrical insulator and became the material of choice in the cable industry.  By the time gutta-percha-encased wires populated Singapore's waters, demand had all but wiped out the local flora that made its transmissions possible.

Selected sources:
Ken Beauchamp, History of Telegraphy (IEE History of Technology Series). London: The Institution of Engineering and Technology, 2001. 135-8.
Chester G. Hearn, Circuits in the Sea: The Men, the Ships, and the Atlantic Cable. Westport, CT: Praeger Publishers, 2004. 10-11.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: When the cable landed in 1859, Muntok was still a small town, with red-roofed houses clustered around a bay and tall, straight palm trees lining empty dirt roads. The engineer who installed the cable wrote of Muntok: “All serene. Great trouble with the telegraphists … who sleep on duty, and otherwise keep Siemens constantly in the station.” Yet after the 1860s, the area became critical to the circulation of goods around the world – Bangka, where Muntok was located, was one of Indonesia’s “tin isles.” By the turn of the century, these islands supplied two-thirds of the world’s tin, including much of the metal used in canning perishable food. One author observed: “Few other metals were so integral to the web of industrialization and mass consumption yet so reliant on trade from tropical territories.” Although indigenous and Chinese miners had long extracted the ore, the Dutch brought new mining techniques to the island, including hydraulic technologies capable of removing fifty cubic meters of soil per hour. Such practices devastated the landscape. Two-thirds of Bangka’s forest had been stripped by the 1920s, and its rivers filled with silt. Though much of the infrastructure of the colonial period, including the undersea cable, has disappeared, mining continues to ground the island’s economy. Muntok is home to the biggest tin smelter in the world, its landscape is scattered with craters, and its waters are polluted with heavy metals.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: “1859 Batavia-Singapore Cable,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed July 19, 2013, http://www.atlantic-cable.com/Cables/1859Batavia-Singapore/.

Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1845-1900,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed July 19, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1850.htm.
Justus van Maurik, “Indrukken van een 'Tòtòk',” accessed July 19, 2013, http://www.dbnl.org/tekst/maur005indr01_01/maur005indr01_01_0021.php.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: You arrive at the “Amsterdam of the tropics,” or so the Dutch East India Company imagined it when they built up Jakarta to support the spice trade. Streets and canals are named after Dutch provinces and cities, and the city is named Batavia, after Dutch tribal ancestors. The oldest part of the town, built near the coast and surrounded by walls, is the hub of a far-flung trade network. To the south, Weltevreden is ordered, regulated, and home to shops and government offices. Through and through, the colonial landscape is structured to facilitate the smooth flows of trade. Yet it is also designed to separate colonists from the Javanese. When the first undersea cable was landed in 1859, the telegraph station molded to the city’s organization. The “cable colony” is now “one of the favourite stations in the Extension Co.” – it has a rambling garden, tennis courts, stables, a reading room, and a broad entryway flanked by palm trees. As is true in the rest of Jakarta, the station’s non-European laborers are excluded from the extravagant lifestyle of the cablemen, relegated instead to neighborhoods “in and around the European city.”

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, "Cable Timeline: 1845-1900," History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed June 29, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1850.htm.
“Batavia: The Exiles' Mess,” The Zodiac, 1922. Held in the Cable & Wireless Archives.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Laid by the Dutch East Indies Government in 1859, this cable was intended to help connect their colonies in the region. Yet shortly after the cable-laying was completed, the line was broken. One man on the expedition recalled, "its fracture by ships' anchors in two places within forty-eight hours afterwards, if it was a source of great disappointment and chagrin, has proved that a cable is nearly as easy to be repaired as it is to be fished up."

In 1876 the Eastern Telegraph Company laid a trans-Tasman cable from Botany Bay to Nelson, where they sought to interconnect with economic trade then centralized in New Zealand’s South Island. A recollection of this link, the first to New Zealand, proclaims: “Cut off by 13,000 miles of sea, and six months in time, from their homeland, British colonists living in remote New Zealand in 1876 suddenly found themselves linked with England—of nostalgic memory—by submarine cable. Thirty-six years of isolation was at an end.”

In Australia, you come ashore where Captain Cook first staked the British Flag in 1770 and where French explorer La Perouse later landed in 1788. Winds whip around the headlands, agitating waves even in the sheltered bay. Although you are ten kilometers south of Sydney, this location was selected as a cable landing in part due to its nautical history, which in turn later attracted military installations. Even after the telegraph station was closed for signal traffic, the building continued to serve the surrounding area. It was used briefly as quarters for Coast Hospital nurses and subsequently as a women’s refuge operated by the Salvation Army. Communications, however, were redirected to central Sydney. The builders of at least one subsequent cable system still toyed with the idea of returning to La Perouse, but decided it was too difficult to move the line. In contrast, nautical traffic accelerated. Just down the shore, Port Botany is one of the nation's largest container ports, funneling consumer products through the bay to the rest of the country. The old telegraph station (now a museum), a nearby watchtower (originally meant to look out for smugglers), and a monument named for the early French explorer are reminders that contemporary transit is rooted in historical currents.

“The outside world, with its quips and cranks, is shut out, and we are a community unto ourselves,” one cableman writes of New Zealand’s first undersea telegraph station, established in 1876. Arriving on Cable Bay's shore, you find it relatively isolated from even the nearest town. With few women present, the cablemen of the Wakapuaka station have formed their own tight-knit family, with bonds built from male comradeship. They spend their off-hours fishing in the bay, playing tennis at the station’s courts, producing a Saturday night theatrical show, and drinking heavily. The most memorable events are recorded in their amateur “newspaper,” the Cable Bay Recorder, which takes a sometimes satirical spin on station life. By the early 1890s, Cable Bay has become a recruitment point and training station for the telegraph company, at times bringing new men in through family contacts. Although station life is flourishing and the staff has increased from only 7 to 17, in the years that come competition from the Pacific Cable Board in the north and a disastrous fire will ultimately force the company to move the landing to Wellington. Almost a century later, all that will be left of the vibrant cable family is "Cable Bay Holiday Park," a campground where images of station life hang on the recreation room's walls.
The Pacific Cable Board's landline between Southport and Sydney was so unreliable that, when the system was upgraded in 1923, it was replaced by a submarine cable.

Bondi Beach is perhaps better known as a world famous surfing locale than as a hotspot for undersea cables. Since the early twentieth century, however, Bondi has been the landing point for numerous telegraph, telephone, and fiber-optic cable systems. Located close to the center of Sydney, Bondi offers proximity for cable companies that seek to move in close to downtown markets. The most difficult part for cable layers is getting from the coastal beaches where cables land to the cable station, located in the center of the city. Given the lack of duct space under the streets, it is difficult to pave new paths in major urban areas.

The expansive Commonwealth Pacific Cable, which stretched across the Pacific from Hawai'i to New Zealand and Australia, was officially opened in 1963. The cable's management committee launched a multimedia blitz to publicize the system, publishing photos of cable stations, distributing booklets about the cable’s design, publicly tracking the cable ships, and issuing special stamps to commemorate the cable.

Port Alberni draws its wealth from the vast forest of British Columbia’s shores. Deep inland, sheltered from the Pacific Ocean by a long, narrow inlet, the town’s early dwellers worked at waterfront mills, stripping the woods around them to make products that circled the globe. By the 1960s, many residents worked for MacMillan Bloedel, one of the world’s largest forestry companies. It not only boosted the region’s economy, but created a social world. Each of its divisions had its own social club which organized gatherings of all kinds and structured local life. Yet in the 1960s and 70s, a new constituency began to oppose the logging of Vancouver Island. Environmentalists called for the protection of nature and the establishment of parks. When the first undersea telephone link, COMPAC, arrived in 1963, environmentalists clashed with the Canadian Overseas Telecommunications Service, since the company had cleared forest to make way for their system. As signals come ashore today, however, surfacing amidst logs and swerving uphill next to the Alberni Plywood Division, they face little resistance.
This cable, originally laid by the German-Netherlands Telegraph Company, was diverted by the Japanese to Palau in 1942.

Sumay, once a thriving Chamorro town, is today a site of displacement and dispossession. The small village was located on the shores of Apra Harbor, and shielded from foreign circulations in part by its coral reef. Pirates and privateers that wanted to avoid the Spanish, who ruled the island from the sixteenth to the nineteenth century, took refuge in the harbor and bartered with local Chamorros. Although the Spanish eventually built forts to secure the area, in 1898 the Americans sailed easily into the harbor and took Guam with no struggle. Under American rule, Sumay changed drastically. The United States established a Marine Corps Aircraft Squadron there. Pan American Airways used the area as a landing for its China Clipper, and subsequently built the first hotel on Guam nearby. The Commercial Pacific Cable Company laid their transpacific cable to Sumay's shores. These businesses played a large role in the economic prosperity of the village, and many villagers worked at the cable station. But when the Japanese attacked the island in 1941, the town's entire population was evacuated. Even after the United States reclaimed Guam, the villagers were not allowed back to their land. Instead, the harbor became home to one the most important naval bases in the Pacific. The only remainders of the community and cable hub are ruins, now overgrown by the jungle, and a small cemetery that villagers are permitted to visit once a year.

A century ago, Yap was a Pacific communications hub, the junction point of three cables linking Guam, Shanghai, and Manado. Colonized by Germany, it was a critical node in their vast cable network of over 18,000 miles. Yap also formed an important bridge between America and China. From Guam, the United States relied on the German-Netherlands network to connect to Shanghai. During World War I, the Japanese seized the island and Yap became not only a “cable threat,” but a threat to the sea route between the U.S. and the Philippines. After the war, the possession of Yap, its cables, and its coaling station was the subject of a dispute between the United States and Japan. Japan claimed that the island had been designated to her under a Mandate of the League of Nations. The United States sought to put Yap under “International supervision” as an international cable station, rather than under control of a single nation. After a year of deadlock, the United States and Japan came to an agreement that split the network, and subsequently eliminated all cable links. Today, Yap remains without cable systems and without high-speed Internet infrastructure, linked only via wireless technologies. A single satellite station carries all of Yap’s Internet traffic out of the country.

Menado derives from the word "manadou" or "wanazou," meaning “on the far coast” or “in the distance.” The town is located on the far northwestern tip of the Indonesian island Sulawesi. The Dutch East India Company built a fortress here in 1658 and from that time it was slowly and steadily colonized and Christianized by traders and missionaries. The thick stone walls of the city’s fort still exist, but outside it, the town grew into a colonial village with hedgerows, streets, gardens, and cottages. In 1905, traveling via Menado’s first undersea cable, you traverse a busy port filled with large trading vessels and smaller, slimmer pinisiq, Indonesian sailboats. The beautiful bay actually makes a bad harbor: the reefs and steep slope in the sea floor provide little anchorage. Between the cable landing and the distant mountaintops, expansive coffee plantations dot the landscape. Although it will never grow into a sizeable port city, this location will remain important to the Dutch in part due to its massive coffee exports.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Strung between Hawai'i and California in 1902, and extending onward to Guam, Japan, and the Philippines in the years after, the Commercial Pacific Cable was the first "American" transpacific link. Secretly, however, it was owned in part by the British Eastern Telegraph company, a trade off the cable layers had to give up in order to gain access to lucrative Chinese markets.

Just south of San Francisco's famous Cliff House, on Ocean Beach, over forty thousand people witnessed the landing of the transpacific telegraph in December, 1902. Eleven-year old Lucille Gage, the daughter of California's governor, broke a bottle of champagne over the cable. San Francisco had been the hub of telegraph traffic on the United States' west coast since the mid-nineteenth century. The first Overland Telegraph, linking San Francisco and New York City, had been completed in 1861. Just over a decade later, this network extended south to Santa Barbara, Los Angeles, and San Diego. From the late nineteenth century onward, San Francisco was a stopping point for telegraph traffic to the west coast and across the Pacific, almost all of which funneled through the city. Today, even though the area is a global center of high-tech development, little of this history remains. Cable systems migrated northward after World War II, and since then, not a single transoceanic network has landed in San Francisco.

In 1893, during an autumn stay in Hawai’i, Robert Louis Stevenson wrote an advertisement for the local news paper: “If anyone desire such old-fashioned things as lovely scenery, quiet, pure air, clear sea water, good food, and heavenly sunsets hung out before his eyes over the Pacific and the distant hills of Waianae, I recommend him cordially to the ‘Sans Souci.’” A decade later, much had changed: the Hawaiian islands had been annexed by the United States and a telegraph cable was strung ashore at Sans Souci beach, connecting Hawai’i to Midway Island. With the completion of this cable, President Teddy Roosevelt sent a round-the-world telegram congratulating the cable’s projector, Mackay, from his home on Long Island to New York City via the Commerical Pacific Cable’s transoceanic link. The message took only twelve minutes. Little remains of this history at Sans Souci today, the only indication of the cable is a brief mention at the bottom of the menu at a local restaurant.

When the Spanish took possession of Manila in the sixteenth century, they brought galleon trade ships, Christian missionaries, and tobacco seeds. They also brought the "polo y servicio," a practice of forced labor in which indigenous Filipinos were put to work on colonial infrastructure and agriculture. By the late 19th century, Manila’s streets were host to both a growing commercial sector and a deep-seated resentment that eventually erupted into guerilla resistance. In 1880, a cable was laid to Hong Kong to Bolinao, extending arduously overland to the capital city. By the time the Manila cable station finally opened for service in 1887, the Philippine Revolution was in full swing. The link was repeatedly cut by revolutionary forces and within a year it was replaced by a submarine cable to Manila Bay. Yet even that cable was not safe from strife – the Spanish-American War started in 1898, bringing about further conflict and cable disruption. When the United States finally replaced Spain as the colonial force in the region, they turned to secure their new territory from the indigenous resistance, leaving up to one million Filipino casualties. Eager to solidify their power in the Philippines, the Americans laid another cable, connecting Manila to the United States via Guam and Honolulu. In the years that followed, they used telegraph networks to surveil Filipino leaders and safeguard their empire.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: "Over 130 Years: Early Beginnings," Eastern Communications, accessed July 16, 2013, http://www.easterncommunications.com.ph/index.php/early-beginnings/.
Arnaldo Dumindin, "Second Battle of Manila, Feb. 22-23, 1899," Philippine-American War, 1899-1902, accessed July 16, 2013, http://philippineamericanwar.webs.com/secondbattleofmanila.htm.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The Japan-U.S. cable network was one of several ring networks laid at the turn of the twenty-first century. It cost over a billion dollars and has connected three landing sites in Japan with two U.S. stations via a direct northern route and a southern route through Hawai'i. Owned by a 35-member consortium, the cable has been upgraded to transmit more than 15 times its original capacity.

Kitaibaraki thrived as a center of coal mining in the nineteenth century, with rail lines connecting it to Tokyo a hundred miles away. In 2011, a 9.0-magnitude earthquake devastated the city. The closest cable station to the epicenter, Kitaibaraki was severed from both the U.S. and Asian networks, though Japan’s cable density allowed much of the traffic to be rerouted. The tsunami also wiped out an important cultural landmark: a red pagoda-like meditation retreat designed by Japanese philosopher and art historian Tenshin Okakura. While this structure was rebuilt in its original location on the rocky shores of the Pacific Ocean, cable operator KDDI announced the construction of a new tsunami-resistant station in Chikura that will stand ninety feet above sea level.

To get to California’s oldest still-operational cable landing point, established in Point Arena in 1957, you would have to travel over a hundred miles north from San Francisco along narrow wooded roads. The cable station is positioned on a bluff overlooking the Pacific. Across the road from the station, families picnic at a campsite. Cows graze in a nearby pasture. Between the station and the beach, a sign restricts access to a “sensitive habitat area.” At first glance these environments, and the signs indicating environmental preservation, appear to secure both wildlife and cables, protecting infrastructure from perception and potential tampering. But such environments also pose a problem to those laying undersea cables. At this station, cable builders had to undergo extra permitting,  and ultimately delay, to ensure that they did not endanger the Point Arena mountain beaver.

Shima is a major hub with connections to five active international cable networks and three different cable stations, but it remains largely invisible to local residents. While cables are hidden, several festivals call attention to the surrounding ocean, known for its abundant marine life since at least the eighth century. Every June, a twenty-foot wooden spiny lobster is paraded through the city streets to encourage a bountiful harvest season. And in September, four men carry an oversized waraji (traditional straw sandal) into the ocean, setting it adrift. This ritual is designed to ward off Dandarabocchi, a mythological giant so large that his footsteps create lakes. Afterwards, spectators gather on the beach for dancing and a fireworks display.

You can journey to the village of Maruyama along cables from the U.S., Australia, or various sites in Southeast Asia. But upon reaching the station, you may feel as if you’ve traveled even farther—and back in time. Across the road is Rosemary Park, a detailed replica of a sixteenth-century English town. Built in 1997 by British architects, the tourist attraction includes a working windmill, formal gardens, a duck pond, and a recreation of Shakespeare’s childhood home, complete with lifelike statues and time-specific furnishings. Shakespeare referenced rosemary in his plays, and Maruyama is known for producing this and other herbs. While the park looks to the past, the modern cable station is one of Japan’s most popular landing sites. Both enact a kind of virtual transit to far-off locales.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Source: “Three-way Link-up launched,” New Straits Times, 28 September 1983: 2.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Note: unconfirmed that SEACOM landed at Katong; not sure if image matches landing

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Long before it was a cable hub, Katong was a center of private wealth in British Malaya. Colonial elites established giant mansions, coconut plantations, and weekend villas along the waterfront in this East Singapore district from the early nineteenth century onwards. Though some of these structures have been preserved and restored, often painted bright colors, the still-affluent neighborhood has also seen some major physical transformations. The beach where you emerge from the APCN-2 network didn’t even exist before the 1970s. It was created as part of a massive land-reclamation project designed to add more space for housing on the island. Modern apartment towers and Singapore’s largest park now occupy the expanded coastal area. Soon after the artificial beach was completed, a telephone cable arrived from Hong Kong, followed by connections to regional fiber-optic networks in the 1990s and early 2000s.

Popular with surfers and backpackers, the small fishing village of Cherating lies approximately twenty miles north of Kuantan on the central east coast of Malaysia. Every spring and summer, leatherback sea turtles swim through the calm waters and lay their eggs on broad sand beaches lined with Casuarina trees. These same environmental conditions are well suited to underwater cable landings: sand is an accommodating medium for cable burial and there are no strong ocean currents to shift or expose cables once in place. Although cables have connected here since the 1980s, the current station was built as part of Telekom Malaysia’s investment in the APCN-2 system of the early 2000s. A single-story complex with pitched roofs set back from the road and surrounded by a security fence, the Cherating cable station is relatively unassuming. But a large communications tower, visible for miles, marks the site as a hub for signal traffic.

As a landing site for the 1983 ASEAN cable, Songkhla was the first station in Thailand to receive underwater telephone links. Cables surface on the seemingly idyllic Ban Kao Seng beach near the country’s largest natural lake, the same place where invading Japanese troops landed at the start of the Second World War. Years earlier, according to local folklore, a wealthy governor from the south of Thailand was sailing up the coast with a fortune in gold when his ship ran aground near Ban Kao Seng. Stranded, the governor ordered his fortune buried, committed suicide, and left instructions for his severed head to be placed on the rocky cliffs above the beach. The name Kao Seng derives from the treasure’s supposed value: 900,000 baht. Some believe it’s still buried there alongside several underwater cables entering the Gulf of Thailand.

Although it was a landing site for the 1997 Asia-Pacific Cable Network, Chao Samran, Phetchaburi never grew into a major cable hub. Later connections favored stations in the south, closer to Malaysia, Singapore, and Indonesia, or the economically dominant Satun across the Gulf of Thailand. A similar shift occurred a hundred years ago during the reign of King Rama VI. In 1918, the king built a royal summer residence on the shores of Phetchaburi province, renamed Hat Chao Samran or “Royal Leisure Beach.” For a few years, Chao Samran was a popular vacation spot among elites. But poor transportation and a lack of fresh water eventually led the king to demolish the residence and rebuild it further south where resources were more plentiful.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/title.value: Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN) submarine cable

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The ASEAN cable was laid in several sections, with its first links connecting the Philippines and Indonesia to Singapore, in 1978 and 1980, respectively. The final section of the cable was inaugurated in 1983 by “a three-way conversation among the Communications Ministers of Malaysia, Singapore, and Thailand,” reports the New Straits Times. With landing stations in all five countries, the cable had a capacity of 1,680 telephone lines and carried telegraph and telex messages as well. But the inauguration placed the most emphasis on the cable system’s political significance. It represented “the unity, understanding, and cooperation among the five ASEAN nations” and “exemplified their strong dedication to work towards common objectives beneficial to all.”

This 1985 coaxial cable network connected Singapore to France by way of the Indian Ocean. It was a massive undertaking involving 21 different countries and, measuring 13,585 km in length, it was the longest telephone cable of its time. It served for 14 years until the introduction of SeaMeWe-2’s fiber network made it redundant.

As you approach Colombo, Ceylon (present-day Sri Lanka) in 1903, your travel guide tells you: “its appearance is extremely picturesque: a fine undulating country, well wooded to the water’s edge and fringed by cocoa-nut trees; lofty verdant ranges tower in the distance, covered with groves of talipat and other palms.” Centrally positioned in the Indian Ocean, Colombo was a key trade port long before the colonial era. In the early 1500s, the Portuguese established a fort and trading post to capitalize on the island’s abundant cinnamon crops. After a brief Dutch occupation, Colombo was ceded to the British and became the capital of British Ceylon. To facilitate faster communication to London, a submarine cable was brought to the island via the Middle East in 1913, connecting to a new Central Telegraph Office in a three-story wood building near the harbor. Messages could now travel between the two cities in as little as thirty minutes, a savings of nearly four hours compared to older land-based routes through India. Today, messages transit in only milliseconds from five cable systems that land in the Colombo area.

In the early 1890s, two major infrastructures latched Medan into global networks: the Port of Belawan and an undersea communications cable. Only seventy years before, Medan had been a village of only 200, but in the intervening years it quickly expanded as a center of trade. Massive amounts of tobacco were harvested from Dutch plantations and shipped out of Medan’s port, including the much-desired Deli leaf for cigar wrapping. When tobacco farming pushed the soil’s limits, American companies created rubber plantations, some encompassing tens of thousands of acres. At one point, the United States Rubber Company held 150 square miles of land and employed fourteen thousand indentured laborers. The social and environmental ramifications of the plantations were huge. Large swathes of forest were cleared by Chinese and native laborers, the rural peasantry was left without land, and chemical fertilizers were spread across the ground. Though the city is no longer under Dutch rule, the colonial infrastructure had a lasting impact. Plantation-financed colonial architecture remains, and coffee, rubber, and palm oil estates continue to devastate the forests. Enormous container ships load their exports at the Port of Belawan, now the second busiest port in Indonesia. And undersea cables, as in the nineteenth century, link Medan’s economy and culture into a global system.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1951-2000,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed June 22, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1951.htm.

Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1845-1900,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed July 13, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1850.htm.
“Port of Belawan, North Sumatera, Indonesia,” accessed July 13, 2013, http://seaport.homestead.com/files/belawan.html.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Before it was cleared for industrial development in the 1970s, Tuas was a small but active fishing village on the western tip of Singapore. Local fishermen would lay palm fronds on the water’s surface above a submerged net, attracting fish with the shade. The name “Tuas” derives from the Malay word for hauling up the net and the catch it contains. Although this technique is rarely practiced anymore, modern-day Tuas pulls together large-scale networks of various kinds. Global cable systems arrived starting in the late 1990s, connecting to the red and white SingTel station, adorned with a series of porthole-shaped windows and a tall, latticework communications tower. A power plant feeds Singapore’s grid with roughly a fifth of its total supply. Near-constant marine traffic flows through the naval base, shipyards, and container port, while waste is transferred to an offshore landfill. And roadways converge at a checkpoint and mile-long bridge that links Tuas to Johor, Malaysia, offering one of the only terrestrial paths off the island.
Completed in 1980 by Japan’s KDDI Corporation, this coaxial system linked Hamada and Pusan. It was decommissioned in 1997 and donated to the Ocean Research Institute at Tokyo University.

For a relatively brief period between 1980 and 1997, you could travel here from Pusan along a coaxial cable under the Korea Strait. Emerging on a white-sand beach, you’d find one of the largest deep-sea trade ports in western Japan, abuzz with ships carrying local fish, seaweed, and wood products. The town formed around a hilltop castle built in 1620 and later destroyed by its creators to prevent it from falling into enemy hands. Hamada’s cable station was also abandoned and dismantled, but for a different reason: new fiber-optic networks offered faster connections between Japan and Korea via hubs closer to Tokyo-Yokohama. While the castle ruins, including a stone foundation and wooden gateway, are now a popular tourist attraction that reminds visitors of the city’s long history, evidence of its place in the underwater network has all but disappeared.

This Korean city has long been a hub for Japanese connections. In the nineteenth century it served as Japanese merchants’ primary access point to Asian trade networks. When it opened, Busan’s Japanese-run telegraph station became an equally important gateway. It handled all Korean telegraph traffic until an overland link to Seoul was completed in 1888, and it allowed Japanese-language telegrams to leave the country for the first time. Cable traffic spiked from a few thousand messages sent between the two countries in 1884 to some 430,000 — the vast majority in Japanese. In 1931, Busan was the site of Japanese experiments for another communications revolution: the use of undersea cables for voice transmission. Today, the city’s two cable stations, which provide a major gateway to the Internet, are finally operated by Korean companies. Yet the country faces another challenge at its shores – from local aquaculture rather than foreign powers. Dense seaweed forests immediately off Busan’s coast twist around ropes bordering the cable’s path. Harvesting the seaweed, fishermen come dangerously close to the country’s international communications lines. Whenever cable companies land a new system, they have to be careful not to disturb the fragile seaweed’s growth. Each cable must be carefully placed in a “mattress” before it is lowered down into the crop.

The first and last submarine link to connect Infanta was landed in 1990. Known as the “gateway to the Pacific,” this medium-sized port city is located on a tiny peninsula that juts into the Polillo Strait, leading to the Philippine Sea. In the 1990s, the city led a double life as a manufacturing center for the province and a quiet escape destination. Straw-roofed resort huts dot the blue-green waters. The city itself sprawls inward with two-story buildings housing banks, offices, shops, and restaurants. Farther inland, logging sites and salt flats ship their spoils to the town. More recently, the city literally had to dig out from natural disaster: a monsoon in 2004 set off a mudslide in the nearby mountains, burying Infanta in millions of cubic meters of mud, water, cut logs, and uprooted trees. The cable escaped the catastrophe, having gone out of service just a year before.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1951-2000,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed July 16, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1951.htm.
http://siteresources.worldbank.org/INTPHILIPPINES/Resources/ElmerMercadoWBCEACaseStudyInfanta.pdf

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Completed in 1989, GPT was an extension of TPC-3 cable, and provided Taiwan and the Philippines a link to the transpacific fiber network. It was withdrawn from service a mere 14 years later and presently serves as a monitoring tool for oceanographic science.

The cost of even a short coaxial system, such at this link between Okinawa and Miyazaki laid in 1977, was not trivial. The cable required over $7 million to manufacture. The repeaters and submerged electronics cost over $12 million, and the installation cost $1.5 million. Together with a half million dollars spent on terminal stations and land equipment, the system came to just over $22 million US dollars.

You have landed on the shores of Okinawa Island, just one island in an archipelago about 300 miles south of the rest of Japan and only 200 miles northeast of Taiwan. Geographically and politically separated from the other Japanese islands, Okinawa remained more or less self-governing until the Meiji Restoration, when it became a target for Japan’s expansionist aims. After winning the Sino-Japanese War in 1895, Japan immediately began laying cables to its colonial territories, including one that linked to Taiwan via Okinawa. For this endeavor, Japan even built its own cable ship, the Okinawa Maru. Following the massive destruction of World War II, Okinawa remained a cable hub, but the station was located far from the island's commercial center, perceived as more vulnerable to attack. Unlike the expansionist telegraph network, the coaxial and fiber-optic projects were collaborative international endeavors. Kokusai Denshin Denwa, Japan’s telecommunications company, partnered with American, Filipino, Chinese, and Korean companies to make Okinawa a stop on numerous transoceanic networks. Several cables continue to have a life even after they became obsolete, now carrying geophysical observations rather than telephone calls.
