“International Workshop on the Scientific Use of Submarine Cables,” Past Conferences – International Conferences with EM components, MTNet, accessed August 18, 2013, http://mtnet.dias.ie/conferences/1997/cables97.txt.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: 1882-?; Manufactured by Telcon; Laid by Eastern Extension Australasia & China Telegraph Company; Seine

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In 1882 another telegraph line was extended between Singapore, a hub for Asian traffic, and Batavia.

Tasman-1 was the second telephone cable laid across the Tasman sea, establishing 640 new circuits between Australia and New Zealand. A state sponsored affair, it was a collaboration of the Australia Overseas Telecommunications Commission and the New Zealand Post Office, and was manufactured by the British company Standard Telephone and Cables Limited. It cost 14.3 million.

When it was completed in December 1937, the submarine cable between Fukuoka and Pusan became part of the longest carrier telephone line in service. From Fukuoka, the six-channel cable ran over the Japanese mainland to Tokyo, and from Pusan, it extended north through Korea and into the Manchukuo region of China, covering a total of more than 2,000 miles. The cable not only improved the quality of commercial telephone calls between Japan and the continent, but also expanded Japanese military communications in the lead-up to the Second World War.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value:
Anton A. Huurdeman, The Worldwide History of Telecommunications. Hoboken, NJ: John Wiley & Sons, 2003. 327.
Daqing Yang, Technology of Empire: Telecommunications and Japanese Expansion in Asia, 1883-1945. Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press, 2010. 165-9.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Fukuoka has been an exchange point between Japan and the rest of Asia for millennia. In the year 57, a Han Dynasty emperor bestowed a gold seal on the King of Na (present day Fukuoka). Over the following centuries, the city’s proximity to Korea and China facilitated international trade as well as the flow of Buddhism and agricultural techniques into Japan. But this proximity also made it a target: Fukuoka was attacked by Mongol fleets in the 1200s, only to be saved by well-timed typhoons or “kamikazes” (Japanese for “divine wind”). Communication technologies only reinforced these ancient economic, cultural, and military connections. Telegraph cables linked the Kyushu region with Korea beginning in the 1880s, radiotelephone was introduced in the 1920s, and the arrival of a submarine cable in 1937 provided long-distance telephone service between Japan, Korea, and China for the first time.

The island of Iki, along with its neighbor Tsushima, “form the stepping-stones between Japan and Korea,” explains a 1912 reference book. For centuries, Iki was an intermediate safe harbor for merchant and pirate ships passing through the Genkai Sea. And in the early 1900s, the island became a stepping-stone for cables. By 1920, seven telegraph cables had landed near the southwestern port town of Gōnoura, which sits at the base of an inactive volcano and is surrounded by rice fields. Four of these lines ran to the main Japanese islands and three to Tsushima, where additional cables carried messages the rest of the way to Busan. When a telephone line was installed in 1937, Iki became a stepping-stone for voice signals on their journey across the Korean Strait.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value:
U.S. Hydrographic Office, Asiatic Pilot Volume II: The Japan Islands. Washington: Government Printing Office, 1910.
U.S. Hydrographic Office, Asiatic Pilot Volume II: The Japan Islands (Second Edition). Washington: Government Printing Office, 1920.
Frederick Converse Beach, Ed. The Americana: A Universal Reference Library. New York: Scientific American Compiling Department, 1912.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: If you could climb up the deep green mountains on the northern end of this island, and look west across the water, you would see the hills of the Korean peninsula rising above Pusan. A small island, about 700 square kilometers of land, Tsushima is equidistant between the Japanese mainland and Korea. Because of its location, it had been a trade center for centuries before the cables arrived, and since has been a perfect locale for international cable connections as well as strategic military operations. Five different cables have landed here since 1891. In 1905, during the Russo-Japanese War, a decisive battle was fought in the waters around the island, which the Japanese won largely through their adeptness with wireless telegraphy. Yet this did not lead to the scrapping of “older” cable systems. Quite the opposite. After the war, the Japanese immediately laid a new undersea telegraph cable: wires complement, rather than replace, wireless.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The French post and telegraph service extended a cable from Saigon to Poulo Condor, and onward to the Dutch East Indies in 1906. The cable, according to one report, was "part of a scheme for endowing France with a general system of submarine telegraphs which would free her from her dependence on the British system."

On a desolate road in Western Borneo, you hear dogs whining and the cry of a newborn child. Watch out, the Malaysians would tell you, this is the pontianak, the vampiric ghost of a mother who died in childbirth. According to local legend, when Arab adventurer Syarif Abdurrahman Alkadrie ignored indigenous warnings and settled here in 1771, he was haunted by the pontianak. Undeterred, he established a Sultanate, and built a mosque, a fort, and a coastal trading station amidst the swamplands. Chinese immigrants transited through Pontianak, and some settled, trading gold mined from Borneo’s mountains. The Arab ruler also welcomed the Dutch, setting the stage for colonial expansion in the region. Even after Pontianak became a protectorate of the Dutch East Indies, it remained a place of encounter and conflict between these diverse ethnic groups. At the turn of the 20th century, the Dutch allied with another colonial power, the French, to make Pontianak a connecting point between cables to Batavia and French Indochina. Unlike the city's varied inhabitants, these links did not have such long lasting effects. It was not until a century later, in 2006, that the next cable landed here, a fiber-optic one linking out to Batam and Jakarta.

“Sultanate of Pontianak,” World History at KMLA, accessed September 8, 2013, http://www.zum.de/whkmla/region/seasia/xpontianak.html.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Marco Polo stopped at the remote islands of Poulo Condor (now known as Con Dao) on his way from China to India, later writing “there is nothing about them worth mentioning.” Yet the archipelago’s remoteness and nondescript character made it an ideal setting for more than a century of incarceration. After taking control of Poulo Condor in 1787, the French constructed a 120-cell prison to hold opponents of the colonial government, including many high-ranking Vietnamese military leaders. While prisoners were detained, French signals flowed freely through the island’s telegraph station. The prison was later turned over to the South Vietnamese and became the site of the notorious “tiger cages,” maintained by the U.S. during the Vietnam War. This isolated island became globally visible when a 1970 issue of Life magazine revealed the prison’s inhumane conditions.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value:

Thomas A. Bass, The Spy Who Loved Us: The Vietnam War and Pham Xuan An’s Dangerous Game. New York: PublicAffairs, 2009.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: You might have come here in 1871, when the China Submarine Telegraph Cable company surfaced a cable from Singapore. Or, you might have come along the 1884 cable, brought ashore by the Eastern Extension company. Despite these outlets to British Empire, Saigon remained in the hands of the French, who finally laid their own system at the turn of the twentieth century. Leaving the city, transmission was slow at times: the government controlled the cable station and international messages sent during times of conflict could be delayed for at least an hour in order for censors to approve them. The cable itself comes ashore far from Saigon, about 50 miles away in rural Cape St. James. A report from the local hydrographic office noted that “the station at Cape St. James was a more healthy place than Saigon, [but] it had some drawbacks,” including potential “incursions of wild beasts. Large tigers were constantly prowling in the vicinity of the station… That the danger was not imaginary was proved by the killing of a large tiger on the verandah of the telegraph station.” Although the area is now a sprawling city and home to over 300,000, it continues to be a critical cable hub, with lines extending out to sea just a few miles around the cape.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: This cable was strung between Pantai Cermin, Medan, Indonesia, and Penang, Malaysia in 1984.

The Kuala Muda station in Penang, commissioned in the early 1980s by Telekom Malaysia (TM), was the country’s first landing site for underwater telephone cables. As the westernmost point on the Malay Peninsula, the state of Penang made a logical terminus for the Indian Ocean Commonwealth (IOCOM) cable from Chennai, completed in 1981. While Penang’s nineteenth-century telegraph connections surfaced in the bustling heart of colonial George Town, IOCOM and subsequent cables landed ten miles north in a comparably remote area where the Muda River flows into the Malacca Strait. By placing the station on the outskirts, TM minimized the risk of cable damage from anchors and trawls of passing ships. Today, the company controls all four of Malaysia’s cable hubs (and five smaller stations), similarly positioned in fishing villages and beach towns on the urban fringe.

The third link between Hawai'i and the United States was a straightforward engineering project. AT&T needed more transpacific capacity, and as in their previous systems, collaborated with Hawaiian Telecom to build the infrastructure that would meet their needs. As a result, the two companies would then own all of the circuits on the system, blocking out any other telecommunications companies from ownership.

Transpacific Cable-2 established a shortcut across the ocean. While all previous cables across the Northern Pacific had stopped at Midway Island, and sometimes Wake Island, TPC-2 jumped straight from Hawai‘i to Guam, leapfrogging the nodes in between.

A second cable was laid by Eastern Extension between La Perouse, Australia and Nelson, New Zealand in 1890, where it would function until 1917, when it was relocated to nearby urban centers in Sydney and Wellington.

Hawaii-1 was the first telephone cable that stretched across the Pacific, linking up California with O'ahu. After 32 years of service it was retired, and it has since been re-purposed for scientific research.

In the 1950s, the first transpacific telephone cable was landed at Hanauma Bay, solidifying Hawai‘i as a hub of Pacific communications. The station was buried underground like many Cold War-era infrastructures, disguised as part of the hillside to prevent it from attack. The burying of the station was not its only impact on the environment: installers had to dynamite their way through a reef to ensure the cable had a safe path out to sea. More than fifty years later, this path has become a corridor of environmental tourism. The hole in the reef, now dubbed the “Telephone Cable Channel,” draws scuba divers and snorkelers through one of Hawai‘i’s foremost nature preserves. The cable, once used to traffic telephone calls, has been re-purposed by marine scientists to monitor the undersea environment, sensing aquatic lifeforms and seismic movements of the ocean floor.

Sanford Fleming and the Canadian Government mobilized arguments about security to establish the first transpacific cable system in 1902, creating a foundational route for all north-south Pacific traffic. This system mastered the scale of the globe: the Pacific Cable Board line between Bamfield, Canada and Fanning Island was then the longest undersea cable in the world. This system also required new expenditures for infrastructure and planning. A new 8,000 ton ship, the Colonia, had to be constructed specifically for the line.

In the 1920s, the Pacific Cable Board lay a higher capacity system directly from Suva, Fiji to Auckland, bypassing Norfolk Island. Thus began the era in the South Pacific of skipping over intermediate islands to ensure more "direct" routing.

In the 1920s, the Pacific Cable Board lay a higher capacity system, a "loaded cable" that eventually transmitted 150 words/minute directly from Suva, Fiji to Auckland, bypassing Norfolk Island. Thus began the era in the South Pacific of skipping over intermediate islands to ensure more "direct" routing.
Eastern Extension's cables between Australia and New Zealand were relocated to Bondi Beach and Titahi Bay, outside of Wellington, in 1917.

In 1917, following a fire at their cable station on New Zealand’s South Island, the Eastern Extension company re-located their links to Titahi Bay, on the North Island. The nature of the company and the culture of the station changed with this move. There was no need to physically man the coastal cable house. Here, the circuits were automatically switched once they came ashore and messages were routed directly to Wellington. Cable work no longer took place in a rural outpost, but in Eastern Extension’s office at the center of the city. Given the World War unfolding at the time, this shift to a population hub seemed to make the cable more secure. Along with the technology of automatic transmission, however, it drastically changed the culture of tight-knit cable operators.

In the 1920s, the Pacific Cable Board lay a higher capacity system, a "loaded cable" that eventually transmitted 150 words/minute directly from Suva, Fiji to Auckland, bypassing Norfolk Island. Thus began the era in the South Pacific of skipping over intermediate islands to ensure more "direct" routing.
This system, the first link from India to Asia, was extended by the British Indian Extension Telegraph Company in 1870.

On December 31, 1870, Madras, India (the colonial name for the city now known as Chennai) received its first underwater telegraph line, which linked India to Malaysia. The telegraph station in Madras was connected in the other direction to overland lines, controlled by the Indian government, reaching across the subcontinent to Bombay. One of the last British ports to be developed, Madras lacked a proper harbor until 1890. Due to the city’s shallow coastal plain, ships had to offload cargo from nearly a quarter mile out to sea, and only then when waters were calm. When the Telcon cable ship arrived, recounts an Australian crewmember, rafts and surfboats were used to bring the line close to the beach before it was “hauled on shore by natives through the surf which is heavy there.” A successful test of the Madras-Penang connection was celebrated with a dinner on the ship and, later that evening, a New Year’s Eve party at the Madras town hall “to which we were all invited, it was a grand affair.”

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value:

Jorma Ahvenainen, The Far Eastern Telegraphs: The History of Telegraphic Communication between the Far East, Europe and America before the First World War. Helsinki: Suomalainen Tiedeakatemia, 1981. 19.
Daniel R. Headrick, The Tentacles of Progress: Technology Transfer in the Age of Imperialism, 1850-1940. New York: Oxford University Press, 1988. 34.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Was located at 44 Northam Road, now Jalan Sultan Ahmad Shah.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In George Town at the turn of the 19th century you witness the beginnings of a modern city. The streets are lined with warehouses and ghauts, wide steps leading from the street to the water. Banks, trading areas, and emporium stores are beginning to appear along Beach Street. Since its founding by the British East India Company in 1786, the town has grown into a bustling trading port and commercial center. George Town has been built on water: its commercial center stands on a swampy wetland that was leveled and filled in the early 1800s. English settlers built their bungalows high up on top of Penang Hill, forbidding natives to do the same. The settlers’ wealthy Chinese business partners were allowed to build in the middle part of the hill. The cable – part of the emerging modern city – surfaces close to the water, but ultimately connected those who lived far above it.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1845-1900,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed June 22, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1850.htm.
Visions of Penang Archives Online (My Heritage My Penang), accessed June 22, 2013, http://www.visionsofpenang.com.my

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The KDDI-owned East China Sea Cable, also know as the Japan-China cable system, linked Reihoku and Nanhui in 1976. A commemorative silver coin shows a dotted line across the East China Sea, bisected by a telephone receiver emitting bolts of electricity. Its 480-voice-channel capacity was interrupted in 1980 by fishing operations and not repaired until five years later. ECSC was eventually decommissioned in 1997.

Reihoku occupies a knob-shaped peninsula on the largest island of Amakusa, meaning “heaven’s grass” and named after its verdant, undulating terrain. Part of the underwater network only briefly, the town was linked to Nanhui by the East China Sea telephone cable between 1976 and 1997. Earlier telegraph lines to China surfaced in Nagasaki while Miyazaki received later fiber-optic connections. The cable’s landing site is similarly bracketed by historical and contemporary infrastructures. On one side are the ruins of Tomioka Castle, built in the early 1600s by a feudal lord and later attacked by rebelling Christian peasants. And on the other is a modern coal-fired power station that generates most of the electricity for the surrounding Kumamoto Prefecture.

Built in the 1970s, the Nanhui station was the first landing site for international coaxial cables in China. Early signals surfaced on the muddy shores of Nanhui district, then mostly farmland, roughly thirty miles southeast of central Shanghai. Now the area is almost unrecognizable, transformed by rapid industrialization that has displaced many of its former inhabitants. Large-scale development projects have even altered the local geography, continuing a process begun millennia ago when Nanhui was formed by silt deposited at the mouth of the Yangtze River. New cables pass by a huge artificial island that contains the recently constructed Shanghai deep-water container port, linked to the mainland by a twenty-mile bridge. And just east of the station, an entire city for 800,000 is being built from scratch on land reclaimed from Hangzhou Bay.

Laid in 1917 between Taiwan and the Penghu Islands, this cable was a part of a concerted program of infrastructure development during Japanese colonial rule. These networks were essential to maintaining control over its colonies, especially after the Tapani uprising of 1915.

The small fishing village of Budai, Taiwan (known as Hotei in Japanese) played an important role in Japan’s conquest of Taiwan due to its proximity to the Penghu Islands. On the morning of October 10, 1895, Japanese military forces departed from their base on Penghu and sailed to Budai. From there, they moved south to encircle the capital city of Tainan. This connection was retraced more than two decades later by an undersea cable between Budai and Penghu, part of the expansion of Taiwan’s telegraph network under Japanese rule. In addition to its ties to military and communications networks, Budai was a regional hub of salt production in the early twentieth century. The city’s seawater evaporation plant employed several hundred workers and produced roughly eighteen million pounds of salt per year.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value:
Yosaburo Takekoshi, Japanese Rule in Formosa. New York: Longman, Green, and Co., 1907. 267.
James W. Davidson, The Island of Formosa Past and Present: History, People, Resources, and Commercial Prospects. London and New York: Macmillan & Co., 1903. 354, 505.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Midway between Taiwan and China, this chain of small islands is strategically important. As a result, even though they are sparsely populated, the Penghu Islands have long been linked to communications networks. In the late 1880s, at the order of the Qing governor of Taiwan, a telegraph cable connected Penghu to China in the east and Taiwan to the west. This was accompanied by gun emplacements meant to fortify the “militarily indispensible” island. Despite these measures, less than ten years later the islands were ceded to Japan along with Taiwan, a result of China’s defeat in the Sino-Japanese war. The Japanese would remain in Penghu throughout the first half of the twentieth century, laying cables that linked across the Taiwan Strait. While the connected cities grew busy with international trade, the Penghu Islands remained apart from the action, with most ships and signal traffic merely passing through. Today, the islands are linked to the rest of Taiwan via another kind of subsea technology: major undersea power cables link Penghu into Taiwan’s electric grid.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1901-1950,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed August 19, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1901.htm.
Jonathan Manthorpe, Forbidden Nation: A History of Taiwan (New York: Palgrave MacMillan, 2009), 147.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Launched in 2010, the Unity cable was the first in nearly ten years to link the U.S. and Japan under the Pacific. As such, it increased capacity along this route by nearly twenty percent. A six-company consortium that includes Google owns the cable, with the Pacnet portion branded as EAC Pacific .

Los Angeles is the only truly urban cable landing on the United States’ west coast. Although it is difficult to string systems into densely populated areas, the more pressing reason for rural cable stations is a legacy of the Cold War. AT&T set up cable stations far from cities in the 1950s and 60s, away from potential targets of nuclear attack. As long as AT&T remained in control, cables stayed at remote stations. But in the 1990s, after the company was broken up, new players in the cable business set up new landings, including this one in the affluent seaside town of Hermosa Beach. From here, cables wind twenty miles inland to a “carrier hotel,” One Wilshire, where it links to hundreds of other networks. One Wilshire, like the cable landing, was also established as a competitor to AT&T. Set up by MCI and Sprint, it was located just three blocks down the road from AT&T’s major switching center. Today it is  one of the country’s most important telecommunications hubs. As Wired Magazine reported, if this building went down “most of California and parts of the rest of the world would not be able to connect to the internet.”

Since the 1880s, Chikura has been known for precision exercises tied to the ocean. Every year, a knife ceremony is held at a local shrine dedicated to the gods of seasoning and culinary arts. Seven or eight men fillet and plate a whole carp using nothing but a twenty-inch blade and a pair of foot-long chopsticks, honoring the town’s legacy as a fishing community. In 1989, Chikura became a site of underwater cable innovation. The first fiber-optic line between the U.S. and Japan landed here, less than fifty miles from central Tokyo, followed by many other cables in the 1990s and 2000s. More recently, the town has become a surfing hub. Several professional competitions are held on Setohama Beach, where well-formed waves crash opposite the prominent cable station.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: 1879-?; Telcon; Eastern Extension Australasia & China Telegraph Company; Scotia; Edinburgh (see AtlanticCable.com)

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Following intense lobbying by governor Sir William Robinson, the British linked Penang and the central hub of Singapore to Malacca in 1879, introducing the latter city to the telegraph network of the Straits Settlements for the first time. The project also served the interests of Robinson’s homeland, providing another link in the chain of communications from Australia to India.

Malacca was an ancient fishing village before it was taken over by the Portuguese in the 1500s, followed by the Dutch and the British. When first telegraph cable arrived in 1879, the port city had both native and colonial populations, and each responded differently to the new technology. According to the British news report from Malacca, the local Malays avoided the cable house after dark, “even now when they see [that] no demon is concealed in the coil of wire.” For Malacca’s European inhabitants, however, the telegraph link was more mundane than mysterious. “One would have thought,” the article laments, “that the laying of the cable would have brought us more into communication with Singapore . . . that the wants of our little Settlement and more news about us would have appeared in the Journals but such is not the case.” Although the settlers did not feel fully connected, the cable had at least one practical benefit: “we get the time more exact than we used to.”

In 2010, the Honotua cable – stretching between Hawai‘i and Tahiti – was made possible by funding from the French Government, granted as part of a wider measure to extend broadband to French citizens and improve the country’s digital economy.

At Papenoo, you surface in an unlikely place: on the grounds of a local school. Until recently French Polynesia relied on wireless means of communication, but due to the scarcity of satellites in the South Pacific, the cost for bandwidth remained high for its approximately 270,000 residents. In 2010 the Honotua cable—stretching out across the ocean to Hawai‘i—was made possible by funding from the French government, granted as part of a measure to bridge the digital divide and extend broadband to all French citizens. Honotua was not seen simply as a technical bridge to a global network, but as emanating from local language and mythology. Ceremonies were staged at the cable landings, where men and women danced in traditional native attire. The cable was named in Tahitian: "hono" means a link and "tua" means the back, backbone, or far ocean. Legend has it that the link traces the route of the Tahitian Queen, who long ago lived at the cable landing site at Papenoo, and had traveled to the landing site at Hawai‘i. The company that laid the system learned of a second coincidence after the cable had already been named. The local mayor informed them that a man residing near the landing had a relative named Honotua, yet another connection of cable to local genealogy.
This cable, originally laid by the German-Netherlands Telegraph company, was diverted to Okinawa by the Japanese in 1916.
This cable was extended between Guam and Japan's Bonin Islands in 1906. It connected the Commercial Pacific Cable's line from the United States all the way to Asia.

On some islands, even finding a shore on which to land one’s cable is a fraught process. Located about 1,000 miles south east of Japan, the Bonin Islands have steep coastlines that make landing difficult. Rocky mountainsides rise up from the blue-green sea, gradually turning from stone into lush greenery higher in the sky. In some spots, small strips of sand slice between the ocean and the hills. In the early 1900s, a cable landed on one of these remote beaches, connecting Guam (and thereby the United States) to Japan. The Japanese had claimed the land only a few decades earlier, and about forty settlers made their homes on the previously uninhabited islands. An American company sent British ships and workers here to land the cable, all of whom were tentatively but amicably received. Like the small beaches that join the water and land, the Bonin Islands were a small but essential solder point between the U.S. and Japan, mediating communication between these two distant societies.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: For decades, Taiwan’s cables have been concentrated at its northern and southern tips. While the Tanshui and Toucheng stations are on the fringes of Taipei, the Chunghwa Telecom station is located in the rural southern township of Fangshan. Most traffic to Southeast Asia, whether from Taiwan, East Asia, or North America, passes through the Bashi Strait, the narrow passage separating Taiwan and the Philippines. Fangshan was the ideal gateway to this route until recently, when a spate of natural disasters severed numerous cable links. An earthquake in September 1999 broke Taiwan’s terrestrial backbone, one undersea cable, and caused cell sites and radio relays to collapse. During the 2006 Hengchun earthquake, submarine landslides took out nine undersea links. Most recently, Typhoon Morakot disrupted six international cables and 1,700 wireless base stations, in addition to taking 500 lives. Fangshan, perched on the edge of the Bashi Strait, is no longer a popular interconnection point for undersea traffic.

North of the original telegraph termination point at Weltevreden lies Jakarta’s post-independence cable hub. The area’s swamplands were once the home to the Dutch Fort Zouteland (“saline land”), and during the Japanese occupation of Jakarta during World War II, Ancol was the site of mass executions and burials. In films of the 60s and 70s, Ancol was portrayed as a mysterious and ghostly place. After Indonesia gained independence, the country’s founding President envisioned the transformation of Jakarta into a great international city, and coastal Ancol as a space for recreation, a “showcase of the nation.” His dreams were not recognized for decades, and even then, they came at a price. Developers dredged the nearby coast, destroying a beach that had made it accessible to Indonesia’s underclass, and converted the marshland for recreation facilities. Today, the theme park Ancol Dreamland, Sea World of Indonesia, resort hotels, and beaches are all accessible only with a fee.

James Bamford, The Shadow Factory: The Ultra-Secret NSA from 9/11 to the Eavesdropping on America (New York: Doubleday, 2008).

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In 1917, the 1890 cable across the Tasman Sea was diverted to Titahi Bay In New Zealand and to Bondi Beach in Australia.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: France Telecom,  BT,  KDDI,  SingTel,  Telecom Italia Sparkle,  Telekom Malaysia,  AT&T,  Belgacom,  Communications Authority of Thailand,  China Telecom,  Deutsche Telekom,  Etisalat,  Telecom Egypt,  CTM,  PT Indonesia Satellite Corp.,  Jabatan Telecom Brunei,  KT,  Portugal Telecom,  Maroc Telecom,  PLDT,  Saudi Telecom,  Sri Lanka Telecom,  Turk Telekom,  Tata Communications,  Chunghwa Telecom,  Verizon Business,  KPN,  Telekom Austria,  SingTel Optus,  Telstra,  Vietnam Telecom International,  Omantel,  PCCW,  Pakistan Telecommunications Company Ltd.,  Cytaglobal,  eircom,  LG Uplus,  Softbank Telecom,  Telkom South Africa,  Rostelecom,  TPSA,  SingTel Optus,  Telecom Argentina,  Telecom New Zealand,  Myanmar Post and Telecommunication

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The Deep Water Bay cable station is situated on one of the most expensive properties in our undersea network. Overlooking a small bay on Hong Kong’s south shore, the station was built when there was little development in the area. Today, it is the oldest still operational station on the island and has been the connection point for numerous cables since the 1960s. In the intervening years, Hong Kong’s affluent residents migrated to the nearby hills and the area’s forest was replaced with mansions. Unlike the typical windowless structures that populate the cable system, Deep Water Bay’s postwar architecture offers a lookout onto the beaches and ocean below. Peering out of the station windows, you have a better view of the bay than Hong Kong’s richest man. There are few people here to enjoy it, however: since it opened, machines have replaced many of the workers.

Stretching a total of 24,000 miles between 39 landing sites, Southeast Asia-Middle East-Western Europe 3 (SeaMeWe-3) is more than twice as long as its intercontinental predecessor, SeaMeWe-2. The optical cable system was commissioned in 2000 by an international consortium of nearly 100 corporate investors.

Madang is fairly small as far as cities go – about 30,000 people live here – but it is the capital and most populous part of its province. The city’s infrastructure is focused outward rather than inward. It is home to many of Papua New Guinea’s export industries, and the landing point for an international fiber-optic cable. The main occupation for many here is a large timber industry, which logs the nearby Gogol forest. In addition, the city exports copra, coffee, cocoa, and tobacco, and is home to tuna processing plants and engineering and joinery workshops. The people are also a mix – tourists, missionaries, and contract workers from countries around the world mingle with indigenous people speaking hundreds of different local languages. Papua New Guinea is considered one of the most culturally diverse places in the world, with over 300 different tribal groups living mainly in traditional societies. Only a small percentage live in urban, modernized centers like Madang and Port Moresby. But even cities within the country have trouble interacting with each other: the volcanoes that run through the middle of the island have prevented any roads from being built between them.

“Madang,” Encyclopedia Britannica, http://global.britannica.com, accessed July 10, 2013, http://global.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/355664/Madang.
“Madang,” The Business Travel Report, http://www.thebtr.com, accessed July 10, 2013, http://www.thebtr.com/pages/australasia/cities/papuanewguinea/madang.htm.

Jan Messersmith, “Madang – The View from Heaven,” Madang - Ples Bilong Mi: A Daily Journal of a Permanent Resident of Paradise, http://www.messersmith.name/wordpress/, accessed July 10, 2013, http://www.messersmith.name/wordpress/2010/04/29/madang-the-view-from-heaven/.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The PPC-1 cable, laid in 2009 to connect Australia, Guam, and Papua New Guinea, has enough capacity to carry simultaneous phone calls from the entire population of Australia – over twenty million people. Countries don't need to have an extensive network in part due to the enormous capacity of fiber optics.

Before Hong Kong was handed back to China, one author observed that it was a “center of espionage, a hive of spies,” with up to 5,000 intelligence agents seeking information for countries around the world. In 1977, the British GCHQ built a satellite base at Chung Hom Kok, on Hong Kong’s less populated southern coast. For over a decade, the satellite base, code-named “Project Kittiwake,” was a center for monitoring Chinese communications and nuclear tests. It was scanned communications about events such as the Tiananmen Square massacre in 1989 and the break-up of the Soviet Union in 1991. When Hong Kong was transferred back to China, Project Kittiwake was moved and the site razed, leaving little for the Chinese to see. At the turn of the century, the Chinese government invested in Chung Hom Kok’s external communications – it was designated a “telecentre” for the development of satellite and submarine connections. Today a new undersea cable station, poised on the edge of a hill and overlooking small fishing boats that dot the waters, still monitors traffic. Rather than intercepting signals sent through the air, communications are now filtered before they are allowed to enter mainland China.

Landing at one of two designated sites on the northern and southern coasts of Changi, you make your way inland to a cluster of stations that form East Singapore’s primary cable hub. Today, the area is known for its major international airport complex, which includes a cactus garden, butterfly habitat, and what will soon be the world’s largest indoor waterfall. But this cutting-edge cable and aviation crossroads has a dark history. The British established a military base at Changi in the early 1900s when the peninsula was still mostly swampland and forests of tall “chengei” trees. During its occupation of Singapore in World War II, Japan used the compound to imprison thousands of captured Allied soldiers. (The prison was rebuilt in the 1990s and now has a death-row detention center.) Even the northern beaches where cables come ashore, a popular spot for picnics and watersports, were the setting for a brutal 1942 massacre of Chinese Singaporeans thought to be anti-Japanese.

EAC-C2C represents the merger of the EAC (East Asia Crossing) and C2C (City-to-City) cable networks, completed in 2007 by Pacnet. Together, they form Asia’s largest privately owned cable system with a total of seventeen landing sites across Japan, Korea, China, Taiwan, Hong Kong, the Philippines, and Singapore.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Globe Telecom,  Google,  KDDI,  Telkom Indonesia,  SingTel,  China Telecom,  TOT,  China Mobile,  Chunghwa Telecom,  Brunei International Gateway

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: You land in Nasugbu only a day after a typhoon has swept through the area, devastating local infrastructure and flooding many homes built on the broad beach. This small town, strategically located on the South China Sea only sixty miles from metro Manila, is the largest network hub in the Philippines. From here, direct circuits link to almost every Asian country. In the 1990s, the Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company opened the country’s first international fiber-optic cable station, which towers over the palm trees and bamboo structures that line the beach. Just down the street is Globe Telecom’s newer facility, an anchor point for the Southeast Asia-Japan cable system. Large walls surround both stations, yet the place where cables enter the water is unmarked. On your journey back out to sea, you pass the remains of a Spanish galleon, sunk by the Dutch navy in 1600. Discovered in 1992, the shipwreck became one of the most important finds in underwater archeology. A replica, along with a museum and resort, were built on nearby Fortune Island but have since fallen into disrepair.

The consortium-owned Southeast Asia Japan Cable (SJC) runs from Singapore to Japan, with branch connections to Thailand, Brunei, the Philippines, Hong Kong, and China. Intense demand along the communication route prompted capacity upgrades less than a year after it was built in 2013.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: REACH,  Telecom New Zealand,  Telstra,  PCCW

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Joining Sydney and Auckland in 1992, the Tasman-2 cable was a major achievement for Australia and New Zealand, and most of the system was manufactured within these countries. The cable's pioneering significance has not kept pace with recent innovations, however, as its present capacity fills only 1% of the company’s regional traffic.

In 1903, the Eastern Extension Australasia and China Telegraph Company was invited by the Dutch East Indies government “to connect Java, Borneo, and Sumatra with the islands of Billiton and Banka [Belitung and Bangka],” notes an issue of The Electrician from that year. “When these cables are established it is expected that they will not only prove a great convenience to the Government and mercantile community, but act as important feeders to the Company’s system” of submarine lines.

The island of Billiton (the old Dutch spelling of Belitung) was a valuable site of tin extraction in the colonial era. Dutch mining operations started in the mid-1800s with the formation of the Billiton Company, named after the island. The company imported thousands of Chinese indentured laborers to perform the heavy and dangerous work in the mines. In the early 1900s, the Dutch East Indies government brought two submarine cables to Billiton’s capital city of Tanjung Pandan, connecting it to colonies in Java, Borneo, and Sumatra. Only a decade later, however, the capital was looted and set ablaze in a worker’s revolt. Belitung and the neighboring island of Bangka are still key points in the global tin trade. The Guardian estimates that in 2012 they produced 90% of the tin in Indonesia, an extraordinary amount given that Indonesia is the second-largest producer of the metal in the world. Environmental advocates recently launched a campaign against Microsoft, a company that uses tin in the production of electronics, accusing them of ignoring the ecological impacts of mining on the island.

Unlike most cable hubs, Palembang is not on a coast, but instead about 40 miles inland from the South China Sea, in the southeast corner of Sumatra. Because of its location on the Musi River, the city has long been a trading and maritime center. The wide, grey river runs directly through the town, dividing the city into halves, and, during the colonial period, easing the arrival of large military and merchant ships. On one bank, a walled city was built by the Dutch, while the opposite bank remained lined with smaller traditional wooden houses on stilts with deep red roofs. The Musi River both divided and connected – the Dutch East Indies Company to open a trading post here in 1619, and by the 18th century, over 50,000 pounds of spices were exported from the city every year. The telegraph cable, brought in 1859, was used in part to transmit information about this trade. The last section of cable had to be laid using proas, local vessels which snaked 60 miles of cable up the narrow and deep river to its widening at the shores of Palembang.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: This cable was launched on October 19, 1992, with a press conference at the Philippine Plaza Hotel in Manila. It was part of the $320 million ASEAN Optical-Fiber Submarine Cable Network, which also included lines between Brunei and Singapore, and between two parts of Malaysia across the South China Sea.

You arrive at a cable station fit for a king. Constructed for the landing of a new fiber-optic network, one cable industry leader recalls that the Tungku station was “built as a palace” so that it could be inaugurated by the Sultan of Brunei. In the following years, the massive station would become a hub of links to Singapore, Malaysia, and the Philippines, followed by connections reaching as far as the U.S. and Western Europe. When a link to the Asia-America Gateway in 2009 created an oversupply of bandwidth, the Brunei government sold it to international carriers in order to finance new cable landings. Located a few miles north of the capital, the station is at once remote and central, surrounded by trees but also a highway exchange and the campuses of both the University of Brunei and an international boarding school. Across the street, a fifteen-story glass office tower (and the second tallest building in the country) contains the headquarters of local telecom provider DataStream Technology Group. When cables first arrived on nearby Tungku Beach in the 1990s, illegal sand mining had caused severe erosion. But the jagged shoreline has been restored and is now a popular place for watching sunsets.

One legend has it that “Kinabalu,” the name of the tallest mountain in the Malay archipelago, is derived from the words for “Chinese Widow.” Long ago, a Chinese prince married a local Kadazan woman, and when he departed for China, he promised to return. She waited for him atop the mountain, where eventually she was turned to stone. In its early years Kota Kinabalu, then named Jesselton, depended heavily upon travelers from the sea. From Jesselton, ships and trains relayed goods with the help of both the British North Borneo Company, who administered the area, and Chinese merchants that funneled products to markets in mainland Asia. Undersea cables, though, bypassed Jesselton to link directly to the more prominent Labuan. Following World War II, when almost all of the city’s architecture and infrastructure was decimated, the town was reconstructed as the capital of North Borneo, which in 1963 gained independence. Major development initiatives were launched in this period, including the SEACOM undersea cable, which connected the city to Singapore and Hong Kong only a year afterward. Today Kota Kinabalu remains the economic and industrial capital of its state.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1951-2000,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, atlantic_cable.com, accessed July 7, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1951.htm.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/title.value: ASEAN Optical Fibre Submarine Cable Network (AOFSCN)

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In the early 1990s, the member countries of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, or ASEAN, banded together to set up this cable system, nicknamed "Asia's Fiber Glove" by one news report. It stretched from Brunei to Singapore, north to Malaysia, and then onward to Thailand and the Philippines. When the APCN cable was laid, this created a redundant loop, ensuring traffic would continue even in the case of a cable break.

When it entered service in 2002, the TGN (Tyco Global Network) cable between Japan and the U.S. offered the highest capacity of any Pacific crossing. Messages travel along this route in as little as .022 seconds. TGN was acquired by the massive Indian company, Tata Communications, in 2005.

Waves crash up against a thick seawall that spans the coast of Toucheng. Much of the shore here in northeast Taiwan is comprised of sand rock, eroded by ocean waves and monsoon winds. Some locals think these spectacular rock formations resemble tofu. Yet the erosion here is not entirely natural. The presence of manmade structures on 56% of Taiwan’s coast, this seawall included, has sped up the disappearance of its beaches. These structures interrupt the flow of sand, causing it to accumulate on one side and to quickly erode on the other. The nearby Toucheng beach, which once stretched for two kilometers, is now severely diminished, and the coast has retreated up to 100 meters inland. This seawall keeps the shoreline intact for both waves and cable stations, but provides an additional challenge for cable laying. Companies have to bore a hole through the thick walls in order to thread their networks through.

By the 1990s, capacity was filling up at Hong Kong’s major cable station, and the cable companies looked for a place to expand. Lantau Island, just west of the city of Hong Kong, seemed ideal. It was to be the site for major infrastructure developments during that period: a new international airport, a trans-bay expressway, and the AsiaWorld theme park were placed in what was otherwise a sprawling, sparsely populated jungle. The station builders chose Tong Fuk for their landing, a small village on the island’s southern shore. When they went to construct the station, however, the village leaders resisted, worried that the cable stations would disrupt the feng shui of the land and bring them bad fortune. The stations were ultimately placed there, but companies careful not to infringe upon the nearby shrine.

Established in 1997, the Asia-Pacific Cable Network (APCN) spans more than 7,400 miles and connects Japan, Korea, Taiwan, Hong Kong, the Philippines, Indonesia, Singapore, Malaysia, and Thailand. A telecom consortium (including AT&T, Alcatel-Lucent, and KDD Submarine Cable Systems) owns this regional trunk-and-branch network.
